  • 20. Setting Aside Sale.
  • 21. Void Judgments.
  • 22. — Estoppel.
  • 23. Confirmation of Sale.
  • 24. Proceeds.
  • 25. Settlement of Estate.
  • 26. Appraisement.
  • 27. Procedure.
  • 28. — Pleading.
  • 29. — Venue.
  • 30. — Parties.
  • 31. — — Contingent Remaindermen.
  • 32. — — Infants as Plaintiffs.
  • 33. — — Infants Not Parties.

    • 1. Right of Partition.

    Where actions of wife in seeking to partition the real property left to her and to the couple’s children in husband’s will would defeat the purpose of bequest, and where children object to such a partitioning, the right to partition may potentially be stopped under this section. McKinney v. McKinney, 888 S.W.2d 332, 1994 Ky. App. LEXIS 124 (Ky. Ct. App. 1994).

    Since, with the exception of an erroneously admitted deposition, all of the evidence supported partition of a property between three siblings, where one brother stated the farm could be divided and that his preferred section was the portion where the farmhouse, barn, and sheds were located, which was agreed to by his sister, the trial court erred in finding that the farm could not be divided without materially impairing its value. Acton v. Acton, 283 S.W.3d 744, 2008 Ky. App. LEXIS 210 (Ky. Ct. App. 2008).

    2. Partition in Divorce Proceeding.

    Where the sale or partitioning of real estate is merely incidental, and not primary, in an action for divorce, the court is precluded from awarding an attorney’s fee to be taxed as a part of the costs and paid out of the proceeds from the sale of the property as would occur in a partition suit pursuant to this section; rather, the remedy would be recovery from the husband pursuant to KRS 403.220. Meredith v. Meredith, 619 S.W.2d 508, 1981 Ky. App. LEXIS 269 (Ky. Ct. App. 1981).

    3. Partition Upon Sale.

    Where testator devised his farm to his widow and three children, devising his widow a possessory freehold estate, a life estate on executory limitation, and devising his children a vested remainder in fee simple with a shifting executory interest in his widow’s life estate, his widow was not necessarily prevented from selling the farm without children’s agreement but, under this section, was required to join all parties to the fee simple absolute and partition the real property or proceeds of any sale of the real property according to each parties’ interest. McKinney v. McKinney, 888 S.W.2d 332, 1994 Ky. App. LEXIS 124 (Ky. Ct. App. 1994).

    Where children/remaindermen objected to the sale of real property left to them and their mother under father’s will, children had a right to seek equitable distribution of funds or an order directing funds be paid to a trustee and invested with the income payable for life to their mother, the life tenant, where partitioning of real property on mother’s request was ordered by the court under this section. McKinney v. McKinney, 888 S.W.2d 332, 1994 Ky. App. LEXIS 124 (Ky. Ct. App. 1994).

    4. Minerals.

    The owners of a surface estate in land containing a severed mineral estate are not necessary parties to an action among the owners of the mineral estate to partition their mineral interest by sale according to this section; where the entire mineral estate has been severed, cotenants in the mineral estate are not required to name the surface owners in an action to partition by judicial sale under this section. Dixieland Distilling Co. v. Keil, 664 S.W.2d 527, 1984 Ky. App. LEXIS 461 (Ky. Ct. App. 1984).

    5. Presumption of Indivisibility.

    Because the language of subsection (3) of this section does not explicitly shift the risk of nonpersuasion to the opponent of the evidence, the presumption language in subsection is governed by KRE 301. Roberts v. Roberts, 67 S.W.3d 605, 2001 Ky. App. LEXIS 47 (Ky. Ct. App. 2001).

    In order to rebut the presumption of indivisibility, it is not sufficient to raise an issue as to indivisibility; it is also necessary to present evidence that the property at issue is divisible. Roberts v. Roberts, 67 S.W.3d 605, 2001 Ky. App. LEXIS 47 (Ky. Ct. App. 2001).

    Trustee was not entitled to sell as a whole property owned jointly by the debtor and his niece as tenants in common because the trustee had not satisfied his burden to prove that partition was impracticable, and the valuation testimony was unsatisfactory; the presumption of indivisibility pursuant to state law also did not satisfy the requirement that partition was impracticable. Higgason v. Brown (In re Brown), 504 B.R. 446, 2014 Bankr. LEXIS 2 (Bankr. E.D. Ky. 2014).

    6. Determination of Indivisibility.

    Before a sale of real estate in which infants have a joint interest can be ordered by the court the fact of indivisibility must affirmatively appear. Shaws' Guardian, Louisville Trust Co. v. Grimes, 187 Ky. 250, 218 S.W. 447, 1919 Ky. LEXIS 388 (Ky. Ct. App. 1919) (decided under prior law).

    Equality of value, as well as of quantity and quality, is a criterion in determining whether land jointly owned should be partitioned in kind or sold and proceeds divided so that the relative vendible value assigned to each party shall be proportioned as near as may be to the extent of his interest. Whitefort v. Barron, 291 Ky. 712, 165 S.W.2d 545, 1942 Ky. LEXIS 314 (Ky. 1942) (decided under prior law).

    Statutory provisions are clear and explicit in permitting a sale of jointly-owned land for a division of the proceeds if sought on the ground of indivisibility only if it is in fact equitably indivisible, the factor of values being an important consideration. Whitefort v. Barron, 291 Ky. 712, 165 S.W.2d 545, 1942 Ky. LEXIS 314 (Ky. 1942) (decided under prior law).

    In determining whether a tract of land should be partitioned between joint owners, the increase of value of an adjoining tract owned by plaintiffs would not be considered. Conyers v. Conyers, 302 Ky. 343, 194 S.W.2d 660, 1946 Ky. LEXIS 674 (Ky. 1946) (decided under prior law).

    Where, although a jointly-owned tract had been purchased as two separate tracts, it had been used as a single tract for several years and there was evidence indicating that only one part had an adequate water supply and that access to one part could be established only at a prohibitive cost, the chancellor’s determination that the tract was indivisible was sustained. Traynor v. Traynor, 333 S.W.2d 943, 1960 Ky. LEXIS 214 (Ky. 1960) (decided under prior law).

    Where several qualified witnesses gave testimony pro and con on the subjects of the divisibility and value of a tract of land and the proof supported the judgment, there was no error in finding the property was divisible. Adams Real Estate Corp. v. Ward, 458 S.W.2d 622, 1970 Ky. LEXIS 180 (Ky. 1970) (decided under prior law).

    7. — Material Impairment of Value.

    A partition may generally be had where a sale would be proper except for the situation where the land cannot be divided without materially impairing its value. Turley v. Turley, 193 Ky. 151, 235 S.W. 18, 1921 Ky. LEXIS 198 (Ky. 1921) (decided under prior law).

    Where the proof showed that to divide the property into eleven lots would make it less salable at a fair price, this constituted a showing that the property could not be divided without materially impairing its value. Napier v. Napier, 233 Ky. 304, 25 S.W.2d 735, 1930 Ky. LEXIS 552 (Ky. 1930) (decided under prior law).

    The property must be divided unless such division will materially impair the value of the property or the value of the plaintiff’s interest in it, and upon the party resisting such partition in kind rests the burden of showing such impairment. Owings v. Talbott, 262 Ky. 550, 90 S.W.2d 723, 1936 Ky. LEXIS 58 (Ky. 1936) (decided under prior law).

    Former section governing sales of property required a division, if such division could be made without impairing the value of the property, or the opposing party’s interest therein. Conyers v. Conyers, 302 Ky. 343, 194 S.W.2d 660, 1946 Ky. LEXIS 674 (Ky. 1946) (decided under prior law).

    The party desiring partition by a sale and division of proceeds has the burden of proving that a partition in kind would materially impair the value of the property or plaintiff’s interest therein. Traynor v. Traynor, 333 S.W.2d 943, 1960 Ky. LEXIS 214 (Ky. 1960) (decided under prior law).

    Where land is owned by two or more parties it will be sold rather than partitioned, only where it cannot be divided without materially impairing its value and the burden of proving that partition will materially impair the value is on the party who pleads indivisibility. Woods v. Woods, 418 S.W.2d 757, 1967 Ky. LEXIS 235 (Ky. 1967) (decided under prior law).

    8. — Partition Favored.

    The law favors a division of land rather than a sale for division, and a sale will not be ordered unless substantial injustice will be done by a partition. Prewitt v. Hurt, 178 Ky. 526, 199 S.W. 33, 1917 Ky. LEXIS 756 (Ky. 1917) (decided under prior law).

    The law favors partition instead of sale if it can be accomplished equitably and fairly. Whitefort v. Barron, 291 Ky. 712, 165 S.W.2d 545, 1942 Ky. LEXIS 314 (Ky. 1942) (decided under prior law).

    All things being equal, as between a partition and a sale, a partition will be decreed. Kentucky Bell Corp. v. Moss, 311 Ky. 114, 223 S.W.2d 580, 1949 Ky. LEXIS 1067 (Ky. 1949) (decided under prior law).

    The law favors partition rather than a sale and the division of proceeds where no substantial injustice will result. Newsom v. Johnson, 255 S.W.2d 33, 1953 Ky. LEXIS 634 (Ky. 1953) (decided under prior law).

    While partition in kind is generally favored, where the land in question is made up of diverse tracts not capable of being divided without a materially adverse effect on the value of the land, sale of the land is proper. Pack v. Ross, 264 S.W.2d 887, 1954 Ky. LEXIS 710 (Ky. 1954) (decided under prior law).

    A division in kind of jointly-owned land is favored over a sale in gross and a division of the proceeds. Traynor v. Traynor, 333 S.W.2d 943, 1960 Ky. LEXIS 214 (Ky. 1960) (decided under prior law).

    9. Joint Ownership.

    Where defendant owned upper story and plaintiff bottom story of building, there was not such joint ownership as would justify an action for sale or division of property. Esther Temple of Mysterious Ten v. Shelby Tabernacle, 124 S.W. 304, 1910 Ky. LEXIS 735 (Ky. 1910) (decided under prior law).

    Where land was jointly owned by the husband and wife, she owning one-fourth and he three-fourths, and he died leaving a will giving to his wife a life interest in a third of his real estate, this was such a joint ownership of a vested interest as authorized a sale under former similar section. Eldridge v. Embry, 158 Ky. 707, 166 S.W. 223, 1914 Ky. LEXIS 700 (Ky. 1914) (decided under prior law).

    Joint ownership by two or more persons and indivisibility must concur before a sale of real estate can be had. Walton Bank & Trust Co. v. Glinn, 161 Ky. 60, 170 S.W. 511, 1914 Ky. LEXIS 16 (Ky. 1914) (decided under prior law).

    Where land descends to a widow and a single heir, they are joint owners, and a sale thereof on the grounds of indivisibility is fully authorized. Lisle's Adm'r v. Lisle, 183 Ky. 656, 210 S.W. 496, 1919 Ky. LEXIS 566 (Ky. 1919) (decided under prior law).

    10. — Joint Owner Opposing Sale.

    Where land is divisible without impairment of value, there is no reason, and therefore no law, compelling any joint owner to sell his property contrary to his will. Talbott v. Campbell, 67 S.W. 53, 23 Ky. L. Rptr. 2198, 1902 Ky. LEXIS 452 (Ky. Ct. App. 1902) (decided under prior law).

    A joint owner of indivisible property cannot be denied the right to bring a suit for the sale of it merely because some other person is asserting, hostile to his interest, right or title to it. Talbott v. Owen, 93 S.W. 658, 29 Ky. L. Rptr. 550 (1906) (decided under prior law).

    In an action for the sale of land and a division of the proceeds, one of the joint owners of three tracts may ask and have allotted to him his entire share of the three tracts to be laid off, in kind, from one of the three tracts adjoining a fourth tract owned individually by him, if this can be done without materially injuring the vendible value of the residue of the three tracts. Prewitt v. Hurt, 178 Ky. 526, 199 S.W. 33, 1917 Ky. LEXIS 756 (Ky. 1917) (decided under prior law).

    Where one tenant in common, or joint tenant, seeks a division, the other joint tenants may ask for a sale of the whole, on the ground that a division cannot be made without materially impairing the value of his interest, and he cannot be required either to pay or to accept money as a compensation for any part of the tract in order that a division may be had. Strode v. Hardwick, 212 Ky. 36, 278 S.W. 168, 1925 Ky. LEXIS 1068 (Ky. 1925) (decided under prior law).

    A joint owner of real property objecting to a sale may have his share set apart if that can be done without materially impairing value of remainder, and a sale of shares of those desiring it may be ordered. Hines v. Carr, 296 Ky. 78, 176 S.W.2d 99, 1943 Ky. LEXIS 100 (Ky. 1943) (decided under prior law).

    Where the value of a tract of land would have been materially reduced by division, the offer of the proponent of division to set off to the opponent sufficient acreage to equal one-half of the value of the tract as a whole did not compel the opposing party to accept a division. Conyers v. Conyers, 302 Ky. 343, 194 S.W.2d 660, 1946 Ky. LEXIS 674 (Ky. 1946) (decided under prior law).

    In a suit for division of land, the opponent of the division was not required to accept a division, where he would be required to construct improvements such as bridges and roadways in order to make his portion of the land usable. Conyers v. Conyers, 302 Ky. 343, 194 S.W.2d 660, 1946 Ky. LEXIS 674 (Ky. 1946) (decided under prior law).

    Trial court properly granted appellants’ motion for summary judgment in a partition action for the sale of jointly owned real estate pursuant to KRS 389A.030, because the statute of frauds, KRS 371.010(6), prevented enforcement of an alleged oral buy/sell agreement between the parties. Smith v. Williams, 396 S.W.3d 296, 2012 Ky. LEXIS 80 (Ky. 2012).

    11. Sale of Infant’s Property.

    Where infants have interest in one tract of land to be sold for reinvestment this tract alone may be sold where it is separate from an adjoining tract in which infants have no interest. Bennett v. Bennett, 143 Ky. 380, 136 S.W. 878, 1911 Ky. LEXIS 425 (Ky. 1911) (decided under prior law).

    There is no provision or authority in law for making a sale of infant’s real estate as a part of or in conjunction with other land in which the defendant has no interest. Conrad v. Conrad, 152 Ky. 422, 153 S.W. 740, 1913 Ky. LEXIS 680 (Ky. 1913) (decided under prior law).

    Courts have no inherent power to order the sale of infant’s real estate; such authority comes exclusively from the statutes, and in such proceedings the method pointed out by the statute must be followed. Melcher v. Yager's Guardian, 159 Ky. 597, 167 S.W. 871, 1914 Ky. LEXIS 834 (Ky. 1914) (decided under prior law).

    A sale of infant’s realty for the purpose of reinvestment was permitted by former similar section. Maiden v. Stewart, 163 Ky. 551, 174 S.W. 5, 1915 Ky. LEXIS 265 (Ky. 1915) (decided under prior law).

    In actions for sale or division of property it is immaterial whether a joint owner is an infant or an adult and where an infant is properly before the court in such an action it matters not that he reaches his majority before the rendition of judgment. Winn v. William, 291 Ky. 258, 163 S.W.2d 473, 1942 Ky. LEXIS 207 (Ky. 1942) (decided under prior law).

    12. — Purchase by Parents.

    Purchase by parents at decretal sale, without court permission, of property, all of which they owned except small contingent fractional interests held by their children was not antagonistic to the children’s interests and in any event could not render void the judgment or the transfer of the title by judicial deed. Foreman v. Taylor, 239 S.W.2d 260, 1951 Ky. LEXIS 875 (Ky. 1951) (decided under prior law).

    13. Creditors.

    A right of sale of property jointly owned is personal to the owner and cannot be exercised by his creditor, the creditor’s right is confined to a sale of his debtor’s interest in the land. Greenbaum v. Commonwealth, 147 Ky. 450, 144 S.W. 45, 1912 Ky. LEXIS 245 (Ky. 1912) (decided under prior law).

    Sale of real property jointly owned by two or more persons at the instance of any creditor of one or more of them, or at the instance of any person holding a lien upon the interest of one of them, is not authorized. Greenbaum v. Commonwealth, 147 Ky. 450, 144 S.W. 45, 1912 Ky. LEXIS 245 (Ky. 1912) (decided under prior law).

    A creditor of one joint tenant can do no more than procure a sale of his debtor’s undivided interest in the property, and this is true whether the land be divisible or indivisible. Marcum v. Marcum, 177 Ky. 186, 197 S.W. 655, 1917 Ky. LEXIS 569 (Ky. 1917) (decided under prior law).

    A lien creditor of one joint tenant or holder cannot have a sale of the entire property, but can only subject and have a sale of his debtor’s undivided interest in the property even though the property is indivisible. Whitney v. Dorsey, 268 Ky. 773, 105 S.W.2d 1025, 1937 Ky. LEXIS 524 (Ky. 1937) (decided under prior law).

    14. Dower.

    Where decedent owned several parcels of real estate and the widow renounced the will, it must be alleged not only that each parcel was indivisible, but also that all the parcels as a group were also indivisible, for the property to be sold free of her dower interest with reasonable compensation to her from the proceeds. Dougherty v. United States, 175 F. Supp. 339, 1959 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 2948 (E.D. Ky. 1959), rev’d, 292 F.2d 331, 1961 U.S. App. LEXIS 3942 (6th Cir. 1961), rev’d on other grounds, Dougherty v. United States, 292 F.2d 331, 1961 U.S. App. LEXIS 3942 (6th Cir. 1961) (decided under prior law).

    The court may, with or without her consent, order a sale of land free from a married woman’s vested right of dower provided a reasonable compensation is paid to her out of the proceeds of sale. Wade v. Wade, 153 Ky. 618, 156 S.W. 138, 1913 Ky. LEXIS 891 (Ky. 1913), rev’d, 154 Ky. 24, 156 S.W. 873, 1913 Ky. LEXIS 6 (1913) (decided under prior law).

    If the estate is owned by the widow as doweress and the remainder by two or more heirs, a sale may be ordered. Vanderpool's Heirs v. Vanderpool's Heirs & Creditors, 171 Ky. 381, 188 S.W. 461, 1916 Ky. LEXIS 366 (Ky. 1916) (decided under prior law).

    Failure of the judgment of sale to provide a reasonable compensation for the widow’s dower in land ordered to be sold on ground of indivisibility, was not ground for setting aside the sale, since the court could thereafter enter such orders as were necessary to protect the widow’s rights. Vanderpool's Heirs v. Vanderpool's Heirs & Creditors, 171 Ky. 381, 188 S.W. 461, 1916 Ky. LEXIS 366 (Ky. 1916) (decided under prior law).

    Trustee in bankruptcy and husband could not have a sale of indivisible property depriving the wife of her inchoate right of dower. Tapp's Trustee v. Tapp, 232 Ky. 355, 23 S.W.2d 549, 1930 Ky. LEXIS 6 (Ky. 1930) (decided under prior law).

    15. Homestead Rights.

    At the suit of infants by their statutory guardian, a court had jurisdiction to sell real estate owned by them, and in which they also had a right of homestead. Jenkins v. McVaw, 145 Ky. 205, 140 S.W. 150, 1911 Ky. LEXIS 806 (Ky. 1911) (decided under prior law).

    During the life of the wife the husband has no such interest in her real estate by virtue of the homestead act as prevents her from forcing a sale of jointly-owned property and the division of the proceeds. Lear v. Lear, 234 Ky. 369, 28 S.W.2d 32, 1930 Ky. LEXIS 183 (Ky. 1930) (decided under prior law).

    A joint owner cannot claim a right of homestead against his co-owner and thus defeat the right of the latter to coerce a sale for division of the proceeds. Colston v. Mitchell's Adm'x, 296 Ky. 1, 175 S.W.2d 1020, 1943 Ky. LEXIS 760 (Ky. 1943) (decided under prior law).

    16. Mineral Rights.

    An estate in minerals may be the subject of partition. Ball v. Clark, 150 Ky. 383, 150 S.W. 359, 1912 Ky. LEXIS 888 (Ky. 1912), overruled in part, Terteling Bros., Inc. v. Bennett, 287 S.W.2d 607, 1956 Ky. LEXIS 473 (Ky. 1956) (decided under prior law).

    A joint owner of an undivided interest in minerals and gases underlying a certain body of land could not, in an action against infants who owned the remaining undivided interest in such minerals and gases as well as an undivided interest in the fee, enforce a sale of all the minerals and gases on the ground of indivisibility. Scott v. Pond Creek Coal Co., 152 Ky. 67, 153 S.W. 23, 1913 Ky. LEXIS 598 (Ky. 1913) (decided under prior law).

    The order for a sale of land was valid where the order was based on a master’s report which stated that the land could not be divided without material impairment of value because its chief value was as a source of minerals which should be worked as a whole and no exceptions to the report were filed. Willimason v. Lowe, 195 Ky. 32, 241 S.W. 333, 1922 Ky. LEXIS 269 (Ky. 1922) (decided under prior law).

    Where a mine or an oil lease was developed by its owners under a mining partnership, one of the members of the partnership could not effect its dissolution by a sale of real estate under former similar section. Outram v. Hudson, 218 Ky. 15, 290 S.W. 1031, 1927 Ky. LEXIS 84 (Ky. 1927) (decided under prior law).

    Partition of mining property will be decreed unless the mineral is so situated that a probable fair division of it cannot be made without prejudice to any of the owners. Kentucky Bell Corp. v. Moss, 311 Ky. 114, 223 S.W.2d 580, 1949 Ky. LEXIS 1067 (Ky. 1949) (decided under prior law).

    While a co-owner of a mineral interest who does not hold an interest in the surface may not maintain an action for sale or division against co-owners of the mineral interest who also hold an interest in the surface, the holder of both surface and mineral interests may bring such an action against holders of only mineral interests. Terteling Bros., Inc. v. Bennett, 287 S.W.2d 607, 1956 Ky. LEXIS 473 (Ky. 1956) (decided under prior law).

    A co-owner of mineral rights may not maintain an action for sale or division against the other co-owners who jointly own the surface in fee. Dawson Daylight Coal Co. v. Beshear, 287 S.W.2d 925, 1956 Ky. LEXIS 486 (Ky. 1956) (decided under prior law).

    17. Sale Prohibited.

    Where a grantor by provision in deed provided that his estate should not be sold until the youngest child should arrive at the age of 21 years and the adult children sought to have the property sold before the youngest child arrived at that age, such action could not be maintained as the prohibition of sale made by the deed was valid. Young v. Young, 49 S.W. 1074, 20 Ky. L. Rptr. 1741, 1899 Ky. LEXIS 309 (Ky. Ct. App. 1899) (decided under prior law).

    Court having jurisdiction of the subject matter and the parties has the power to determine whether or not a will forbids the sale of jointly-owned land, and its judgment, even if incorrect, is merely erroneous and not void, and cannot be collaterally attacked. Houser v. Paducah Lands Co., 157 Ky. 252, 162 S.W. 1113, 1914 Ky. LEXIS 260 (Ky. 1914) (decided under prior law).

    Former similar section did not permit a sale if forbidden by the deed, will or contract under which the property was held. Highfill v. Konnerman, 241 Ky. 282, 43 S.W.2d 657, 1931 Ky. LEXIS 38 (Ky. 1931) (decided under prior law).

    18. Sale Improper.

    Where petition showed the infant’s real estate to be already divided into two tracts, and the decree disclosed a further subdivision of one of them into town lots, sale was not warranted. Walton Bank & Trust Co. v. Glinn, 161 Ky. 60, 170 S.W. 511, 1914 Ky. LEXIS 16 (Ky. 1914) (decided under prior law).

    Where judgment directed sale of land on credit and payment of infant’s interest in purchase money to his guardian, the commissioner’s sale for cash, which he received, was not in accordance with the judgment and could not thereafter be ratified as to the rights of the infant. Miller v. Halsey, 327 S.W.2d 943, 1959 Ky. LEXIS 80 (Ky. 1959) (decided under prior law).

    19. Sale Proper.

    The fact that a testator provides that land devised to one person for life, remainder to others, shall remain in possession of the life tenant as long as he lives, and at his death be sold and the proceeds be divided among the remaindermen, cannot be regarded as forbidding a sale of the land during the life of the life tenant for the purpose of reinvestment. Luttrell v. Wells, 97 Ky. 84, 30 S.W. 10, 16 Ky. L. Rptr. 812, 1895 Ky. LEXIS 157 (Ky. 1895) (decided under prior law).

    Where lands of an estate were devised in trust for testator’s son and his wife, during their lives, with remainder over to any child or children born to them, and in the event no child or children were born to them and survived the wife, or in the event such child or children did survive and die under the age of 21, the property at the termination of the lives of the life beneficiaries should go to the other children of the testator, and where provision was made by codicil that if the wife should die, and the son should marry again and have children as a result of that union, they were to take an interest in the share devised to the son, the wife having died, leaving an only child over 21 years of age and the son not having again married, the court could empower the trustee to sell the land, provided it averred and proved that the sale would be beneficial to all parties concerned. Burge v. Fidelity Trust & Safety Vault Co., 112 Ky. 683, 66 S.W. 763, 23 Ky. L. Rptr. 1925, 1902 Ky. LEXIS 226 (Ky. 1902) (decided under prior law).

    In action by an infant, by her statutory guardian, for sale of a tract of land owned jointly by the infant and the defendant, subject to an unassigned dower right of the father of the infant in her one-half of the land, where it was not only alleged but proved, though not denied, that the land was in possession of the parties to the action and could not be divided without impairing its value or the value of the plaintiff’s interest therein, it was error in the court to dismiss the action and deny the relief sought. Wormald's Guardian v. Heinze, 90 S.W. 1064, 28 Ky. L. Rptr. 1022 (1906) (decided under prior law).

    Court had jurisdiction to sell land where suit was filed upon the ground that the property could not be divided without materially impairing its value or the value of each of the interests therein, and that it was greatly to the interest of all concerned to have it sold. Currey's Guardian v. Monsch's Guardian, 104 S.W. 313, 31 Ky. L. Rptr. 856 (1907) (decided under prior law).

    In action for the sale of real estate and the investment of the proceeds, it appearing that the property was not liable to enhance in value, and that the proceeds were to be invested in real estate of equal value which would produce a greater income, the facts disclosed satisfied the provisions of former section governing sale of remainder. Bethshares v. Allison, 141 Ky. 643, 133 S.W. 555, 1911 Ky. LEXIS 54 (Ky. 1911) (decided under prior law).

    Provision in will empowering the trustee named therein to sell and convey the real estate in his discretion, but withholding such power from any subsequent trustee, would not be construed as forbidding a sale for reinvestment. Marshall v. Anderson's Trustee, 157 Ky. 117, 162 S.W. 559, 1914 Ky. LEXIS 228 (Ky. 1914) (decided under prior law).

    Where a testator devised his land to his wife in trust for the testator’s family until his youngest child should become of age, with the proviso, however, that when the eldest child should become of age his estate might be divided, and it appeared, in action for sale and division, after the eldest child had become of age, that the testator’s land could not be divided without materially impairing its value, the court had jurisdiction to sell the land for a division of the proceeds. Moore v. Potter-Matlock Trust Co., 167 Ky. 201, 180 S.W. 789, 1915 Ky. LEXIS 864 (Ky. 1915) (decided under prior law).

    A trust estate in lands for the life of one person with remainder over to another if he is living, and with reversion to the grantor in the deed of trust if he is not living at the termination of the life estate, may be sold and conveyed by the trustee for reinvestment of the proceeds where such sale is beneficial to all parties and is approved or directed by court of competent jurisdiction in an action to which all persons having a vested or contingent interest in the land are parties and in which the beneficial facts are averred and proved. Lowry v. Berry, 178 Ky. 656, 199 S.W. 809, 1918 Ky. LEXIS 445 (Ky. 1918) (decided under prior law).

    Where the owner of a tract containing 110 acres conveyed 93 acres thereof without describing them except by reciting that this left 17 acres to be taken off the north side of the farm, which was so indefinitely described as to be incapable of location, the grantee thereby acquired an interest in the whole tract as tenant in common with the grantor and in the proportion the number of acres conveyed bore to the whole estate and could maintain action for sale of land and division of proceeds. Speer v. Hall, 196 Ky. 597, 245 S.W. 282, 1922 Ky. LEXIS 574 (Ky. 1922) (decided under prior law).

    Where one of the joint interests is held in fee simple with the present right of possession, the property may be sold for the purpose of division when it cannot be divided in kind notwithstanding other undivided shares are held by life tenants and remaindermen although by defeasible titles. Cammack v. Allen, 199 Ky. 268, 250 S.W. 963, 1923 Ky. LEXIS 807 (Ky. 1923) (decided under prior law).

    The sale of land to a cotenant at 86 percent of its value was proper where the evidence indicated that the land was undeveloped and was declining in value. Burchfield v. Asher, 222 Ky. 108, 300 S.W. 331, 1927 Ky. LEXIS 868 (Ky. 1927) (decided under prior law).

    Where it was shown in suit for sale of devised land that the property could not be divided without impairment, that the farm was in a run-down condition, that the scant improvements were in bad repair and there was doubt as to whether repairs and improvements needed could be supplied, that real estate prices were high and that later economical situation might be such as to result in a slump and that a reinvestment could result in purchase of land better adapted to the maturing of a profitable crop, it was shown that sale of the land would be proper or beneficial to the parties under disability. Kelly v. Marr, 299 Ky. 447, 185 S.W.2d 945, 1945 Ky. LEXIS 445 (Ky. 1945) (decided under prior law).

    Former section authorizing sale of remainders authorized sale of the property for reinvestment where plaintiff was a life tenant and the defendants, whether under disability or not, were the remaindermen. Lowery v. Madden, 308 Ky. 342, 214 S.W.2d 592, 1948 Ky. LEXIS 942 (Ky. 1948) (decided under prior law).

    Where an executor was granted power in a will to sell property devised to the widow and two sons with their written consent this power was extinguished by the death of one son but the widow, remaining son and guardian of deceased son’s children could sell the property through proper judicial proceedings. Whisman v. McMullan's Ex'r, 312 Ky. 402, 227 S.W.2d 926, 1950 Ky. LEXIS 662 (Ky. 1950) (decided under prior law).

    Where real estate was held one-half by fee simple and the other half equally by two holders of defeasible fees, which were subject to divestment upon the death of the holder without heirs, the real estate could be sold. Malone v. Jamison, 312 Ky. 249, 227 S.W.2d 179, 1950 Ky. LEXIS 627 (Ky. 1950) (decided under prior law).

    Realty, which was left by a testator to his widow for so long as she remained his widow with a gift over upon her remarriage of one-third to each her and their two daughters, could be sold while the widow remained unmarried and there were infant children of one daughter surviving. Gill v. Phelps, 313 Ky. 217, 230 S.W.2d 892, 1950 Ky. LEXIS 847 (Ky. 1950) (decided under prior law).

    In an action to sell real estate, where the trial court, on sufficient evidence, found that such a sale would be beneficial to all vested and contingent interest holders and all the procedural requirements were met, the judgment ordering the sale was affirmed. Weddle v. Weddle, 280 S.W.2d 509, 1955 Ky. LEXIS 165 (Ky. 1955) (decided under prior law).

    20. Setting Aside Sale.

    In action by executor of an estate against the heirs, alleging that a sale of the testator’s real estate, or a part thereof, was necessary to pay the debts and legacies, and further alleging that the real estate could not be advantageously divided among the numerous devisees of said testator, the allegations substantially complied with the requirements of former similar section, and sale of the entire property was binding on the infants who seek to set it aside. Zehnder v. Schoenbachler, 70 S.W. 278, 24 Ky. L. Rptr. 947 (1902) (decided under prior law).

    Neither the failure of the court to take proof as to the indivisibility of the land nor the question as to whether it could have been divided without material impairment of its value were matters upon which the infant or purchasers could rely to set aside the sale, since the infant was not prejudiced, as the judgment compensated her for the value of her contingent right of dower in her husband’s part of the land, and the commissioner, as directed by the judgment, took a separate bond from the purchasers of the sale payable to himself for the value of her dower, out of which she would be paid; and, the question whether the land could have been divided between the joint owners, instead of being sold, was one in which the purchasers were not concerned. Finney v. Finney, 144 Ky. 114, 138 S.W. 257, 1911 Ky. LEXIS 611 (Ky. 1911) (decided under prior law).

    Where exceptions to sale were filed on ground that the real estate was in lien for the payment of debts for a period not yet expired, exceptions were properly sustained and sale set aside. Parrish v. Redmon, 285 Ky. 613, 148 S.W.2d 680, 1941 Ky. LEXIS 417 (Ky. 1941) (decided under prior law).

    Where spouses each owned an undivided one-half interest in realty, which was subject to mortgages securing notes on which they were jointly liable, the payment of these notes by the husband after the wife’s death entitled him to be subrogated to the rights of the mortgagee but did not, in the absence of foreclosure, vest him with her fee or constitute grounds for setting aside the sale of the realty, although he would have a lien against the proceeds of the sale. Hollon v. Rose, 268 S.W.2d 641, 1954 Ky. LEXIS 917 (Ky. 1954) (decided under prior law).

    Where the price is grossly inadequate, only slight evidence of fraud or irregularity is required to set aside a sale, but, where there was no allegation of fraud or irregularity, inadequacy of price does not justify setting aside the sale even though the evidence indicated the property to be worth $10,500 and it was sold for $500. Gross v. Gross, 350 S.W.2d 470, 1961 Ky. LEXIS 98 (Ky. 1961) (decided under prior law).

    21. Void Judgments.

    Judgment and sale of infants’ indivisible shares in real estate are void, unless the whole of the land was sold. Alexander v. Tipton, 218 Ky. 666, 291 S.W. 1019, 1927 Ky. LEXIS 207 (Ky. 1927) (decided under prior law).

    Title acquired by the grantee of the purchaser, in action for sale of indivisible property jointly owned, could not be affected by errors in the proceedings through which his grantor acquired title unless the judgment and the sale thereunder were void. Ohio Oil Co. v. West, 284 Ky. 796, 145 S.W.2d 1035, 1940 Ky. LEXIS 566 (Ky. 1940) (decided under prior law).

    Where, following wife’s death, husband brought action against wife’s heirs, asking for sale of real estate subject to his curtesy interest, in which action all heirs were properly served, but husband later filed an amended petition asking that the real estate be sold free of his curtesy right and that he be paid the value of his curtesy right in cash, and no service was made on the amended petition, judgment fixing value of husband’s curtesy interest at a percentage of the sale price and ordering the real estate to be sold was entirely void, because of the failure to make service, and it was error for the court to set aside the judgment only to the extent it ordered a sale of the land. Beach v. Hopperton's Ex'r, 303 Ky. 272, 196 S.W.2d 894, 1946 Ky. LEXIS 789 (Ky. 1946) (decided under prior law).

    It is beyond the power of the court to approve an offer; rather the function of the court is to approve a sale pursuant to a binding offer, not to try to breathe life into a dead offer, and a judgment approving a sale “in accordance with the terms and conditions of said contract” when there was no contract was obviously a nullity. Athens Christian Church v. Stevens, 561 S.W.2d 103, 1977 Ky. App. LEXIS 890 (Ky. Ct. App. 1977) (decided under prior law).

    Where an offer to buy land from a life tenant had expired by its own terms over two and one-half years before the court entered judgment approving the sale, such judgment was invalid. Athens Christian Church v. Stevens, 561 S.W.2d 103, 1977 Ky. App. LEXIS 890 (Ky. Ct. App. 1977) (decided under prior law).

    Where there was a total absence of evidence concerning the “terms” of the contract, where the contingent remaindermen were infants and a church, where the offer to buy was made to a life tenant who had previously abused his trust through a cousin who conveniently wrote himself into the contract for an excessive real estate commission, and where the life tenant and the remaindermen were required to finance some 80% of the purchase price, there was an obligation on the part of the court, pursuant to repeated requests by the contingent remaindermen, to investigate the solvency and financial condition of the offeror to determine that the terms and conditions of the offer could be met and performed by the offeror and, in the absence thereof, there was a breach of duty by the chancellor. Athens Christian Church v. Stevens, 561 S.W.2d 103, 1977 Ky. App. LEXIS 890 (Ky. Ct. App. 1977) (decided under prior law).

    22. — Estoppel.

    Where an infant after he became of age collected his part of the purchase money arising from a void judicial sale of his interest in land which he allowed the grantee to hold for many years, without asserting any claim thereto, he was estopped to claim any interest in the land. Sudduth v. Rowland, 164 Ky. 351, 175 S.W. 646, 1915 Ky. LEXIS 382 (Ky. 1915) (decided under prior law).

    23. Confirmation of Sale.

    Where commissioner did not make sale in accordance with direction of judgment, burden was upon party seeking to have sale confirmed to show that rights of other parties had not been prejudiced. Miller v. Halsey, 327 S.W.2d 943, 1959 Ky. LEXIS 80 (Ky. 1959) (decided under prior law).

    24. Proceeds.

    Sale of land, in action for sale and division of the proceeds, held to pass good and complete title to the purchaser, notwithstanding a one-fourth interest was vested in a trustee for contingent remaindermen, where the court protected the interest of contingent remaindermen by requiring the proceeds of such interest be reinvested in other property upon terms and conditions of the will from which the interest arose. Walsh v. Parr's Ex'r, 110 S.W. 300, 33 Ky. L. Rptr. 242 (1908) (decided under prior law).

    Where upon submission for an order of sale, all of the pleadings, proof and exhibits show a sale of indivisible property jointly owned and in possession is necessary, a judgment and order of sale is not premature because the master has not reported under a reference affecting only the proper distribution of the proceeds among the joint owners. Hosch v. Hosch's Ex'rs, 181 Ky. 781, 205 S.W. 963, 1918 Ky. LEXIS 626 (Ky. 1918) (decided under prior law).

    The owners of a life estate, who also own fee simple title to and are in possession of a fractional part of real estate which has been sold are not entitled to receive the cash value of their interest in that portion of the land in which they own a life estate according to the expectancy of the life tenant upon whose life such estate is predicated for the remaindermen have a right to the substituted principal undiminished at the termination of the life estate. Divine v. Divine, 305 Ky. 486, 204 S.W.2d 804, 1947 Ky. LEXIS 846 (Ky. 1947) (decided under prior law).

    Where real estate, held one-half by fee simple and the other half equally by two holders of defeasible fees, subject to divestment upon the death of the holder without heirs, is sold, the holder of the fee simple is entitled to one-half of the net proceeds immediately and the other half must be paid into court, reinvested and held until it can be definitely determined who is entitled to it. Malone v. Jamison, 312 Ky. 249, 227 S.W.2d 179, 1950 Ky. LEXIS 627 (Ky. 1950) (decided under prior law).

    25. Settlement of Estate.

    In a suit to sell indivisible estate in which an infant has an interest, the estate of the deceased may be settled under KRS 395.510. Baxter Realty Co. v. Martin, 185 Ky. 697, 216 S.W. 110, 1919 Ky. LEXIS 361 (Ky. 1919) (decided under prior law).

    26. Appraisement.

    Land sold upon the ground of indivisibility need not be appraised and a provision in the judgment of sale directing an appraisement, which was made, did not affect the purchaser’s title. Green v. Thomson, 168 Ky. 40, 181 S.W. 662, 1916 Ky. LEXIS 505 (Ky. 1916) (decided under prior law).

    Where sale was not to pay debts but was solely for the purpose of division, no appraisement was necessary. Hosch v. Hosch's Ex'rs, 181 Ky. 781, 205 S.W. 963, 1918 Ky. LEXIS 626 (Ky. 1918) (decided under prior law).

    Law requiring an appraisement applies to all coercive sales for the payment of debts, but does not apply to sales of land made for a division of the proceeds. Lisle's Adm'r v. Lisle, 183 Ky. 656, 210 S.W. 496, 1919 Ky. LEXIS 566 (Ky. 1919) (decided under prior law).

    The fact that a settlement of the decedent and the payment of his debts were asked as mere incidents to the main relief sought, did not make the sale coercive in character, so as to require appraisement of the property. Lisle's Adm'r v. Lisle, 183 Ky. 656, 210 S.W. 496, 1919 Ky. LEXIS 566 (Ky. 1919) (decided under prior law).

    KRS 426.520, requiring appraisal of real estate before judicial sale, did not apply to sales of real estate under former similar section. Hollon v. Rose, 268 S.W.2d 641, 1954 Ky. LEXIS 917 (Ky. 1954) (decided under prior law).

    27. Procedure.

    28. — Pleading.

    An allegation that four tracts of land were in the devisees’ possession and could not be divided in accordance with provisions of the will without a material impairment in the value of the land and of the plaintiffs’ interest was sufficient compliance with the provisions of former similar section. Shaws' Guardian, Louisville Trust Co. v. Grimes, 187 Ky. 250, 218 S.W. 447, 1919 Ky. LEXIS 388 (Ky. Ct. App. 1919) (decided under prior law).

    29. — Venue.

    Action by devisees under will was properly brought in the county in which the land was situated, although that was not the county in which the personal representative of the testator was qualified. Perkins v. McCarley, 97 Ky. 43, 29 S.W. 867, 16 Ky. L. Rptr. 801, 1895 Ky. LEXIS 146 (Ky. 1895) (decided under prior law).

    The fact that an infant owns jointly, with other parties, land in Franklin County does not confer upon the Franklin Circuit Court jurisdiction to sell the land jointly owned by him with others lying in Jefferson County. Goldsmith's Adm'r v. Hieatt, 90 S.W. 259, 28 Ky. L. Rptr. 741 (1906) (decided under prior law).

    An action brought by part of the devisees against the other devisees seeking a sale and division of the proceeds of sale of lands devised under will, must be brought in the county where the personal representative qualified; such action being merely a form of partition and controlled by KRS 452.420. Boreing v. Melcon, 159 Ky. 14, 166 S.W. 612, 1914 Ky. LEXIS 729 (Ky.), modified, 159 Ky. 623, 167 S.W. 870, 1914 Ky. LEXIS 833 (Ky. 1914) (decided under prior law).

    30. — Parties.

    Present and contingent interests in land may be sold for reinvestment so as to pass good title to the purchaser, all parties interested being made parties to the proceedings. Harris v. Anderson, 11 Ky. Op. 230, 3 Ky. L. Rptr. 237, 1881 Ky. LEXIS 254 (Ky. Ct. App. Sept. 17, 1881) (decided under prior law).

    Where an infant owner of a reversion or a remainder in real estate is not made a party to a suit for the sale of the same, sale for reinvestment cannot be justified. Walton Bank & Trust Co. v. Glinn, 161 Ky. 60, 170 S.W. 511, 1914 Ky. LEXIS 16 (Ky. 1914) (decided under prior law).

    Where a testator devised a share of his estate to the children of his nephew and to their children for 21 years after the death of the first taker without making any disposition of the remainder, the remainder was undevised estate and passed, under the will, to the heirs at law of the testator, and they were necessary parties to a suit seeking a sale of the property. Clay v. Clay, 181 Ky. 181, 203 S.W. 1080, 1918 Ky. LEXIS 502 (Ky. 1918) (decided under prior law).

    In an action for sale of real estate, half of which was held by defeasible fees, the persons who held the executory interests, which would become possessory only if a defeasible fee holder died without heirs, were necessary parties. Malone v. Jamison, 312 Ky. 249, 227 S.W.2d 179, 1950 Ky. LEXIS 627 (Ky. 1950) (decided under prior law).

    In an action against the owner of an undivided one-half interest in realty for sale of the property, the court did not err in permitting an assignee of an interest in the other undivided one-half interest to be made a party to the action. Hollon v. Rose, 268 S.W.2d 641, 1954 Ky. LEXIS 917 (Ky. 1954) (decided under prior law).

    Joinder of the living children of the testator’s granddaughter was not required for a valid sale where the testator left the property to his grandson for life, remainder to the grandson’s heirs and upon the failure of any heirs of the grandson to survive him the property would revert to the estate and pass as intestate property. Call v. Call, 367 S.W.2d 274, 1963 Ky. LEXIS 22 (Ky. 1963) (decided under prior law).

    Where the petitioners appealed a circuit court’s dismissal of their petition to order the sale of a tract of land, they failed to demonstrate title to the tract in question as no part of the deed vested them with legal title to the land described in that deed sufficient for the purpose of their action. Their claim of ownership relied solely upon an interpretation of the deed itself, and neither the petitioners nor the appellees were named as grantees in either the caption or the body of the deed. Branham v. Estate of Elkins, 425 S.W.3d 103, 2014 Ky. App. LEXIS 17 (Ky. Ct. App. 2014).

    31. — — Contingent Remaindermen.

    Contingent remaindermen required to be made parties to an action could join with the life tenants as plaintiffs if they so desired. Whittaker v. Chenault, 192 Ky. 81, 232 S.W. 391, 1921 Ky. LEXIS 27 (Ky. 1921) (decided under prior law).

    Where there were contingent remaindermen, all of whom could not be identified, a sale of realty was proper because some of the contingent remaindermen were parties and their interests were mutual and common with all contingent remaindermen. Powell v. Childers, 314 Ky. 45, 234 S.W.2d 158, 1950 Ky. LEXIS 1008 (Ky. 1950) (decided under prior law).

    If the life tenant is not made a party, nobody represents the remaindermen, and the fact that the life tenant may have enjoyed the income from the proceeds of the sale is no basis for estopping the remaindermen. Field v. Lloyd, 453 S.W.2d 570, 1970 Ky. LEXIS 320 (Ky. 1970) (decided under prior law).

    The only basis on which the rights of a contingent remainderman may be sold, without his having been made a party, is that he is virtually represented by the life tenant in the proceeding. Field v. Lloyd, 453 S.W.2d 570, 1970 Ky. LEXIS 320 (Ky. 1970) (decided under prior law).

    32. — — Infants as Plaintiffs.

    In action for sale of indivisible land, it was not necessary for the infant plaintiffs to have representation other than that of their guardian; they were coplaintiffs with her, and it was not necessary for them to have any other representation in the proceeding. Larrabee v. Larrabee, 71 S.W. 645, 24 Ky. L. Rptr. 1423 (1903) (decided under prior law).

    Where property was owned jointly by and was in the possession of two infants, and could not be divided without materially impairing its value, it could be sold in an action brought by their common guardian in their behalf, without naming either as a party plaintiff or defendant. In such a case the infants will be deemed and treated as parties plaintiff in the action as brought for them by the guardian. Ellis v. Smith's Guardian, 147 Ky. 99, 143 S.W. 776, 1912 Ky. LEXIS 192 (Ky. 1912) (decided under prior law).

    A suit may be brought by the infants through their statutory guardian as plaintiffs, and it is not necessary that they should be made defendants or served with process. Baxter Realty Co. v. Martin, 185 Ky. 697, 216 S.W. 110, 1919 Ky. LEXIS 361 (Ky. 1919) (decided under prior law).

    In an action brought for the purpose of dividing land partly owned by an infant or for its sale or division, it was not necessary for the infant owner or owners to be made defendants and duly summoned and defense made for them in the cause, but the action could be maintained in the name of the infant as plaintiff by his statutory guardian or by such guardian alone. Clark v. Satterfield's Adm'r, 233 Ky. 600, 26 S.W.2d 516, 1930 Ky. LEXIS 616 (Ky. 1930) (decided under prior law).

    Where a guardian for an infant files an answer adopting the allegations of the petition and joining in the relief asked, such guardian becomes substantially a party plaintiff in the suit, yet to reach such a result it is necessary that the guardian filing such an answer be one with authority to sue in this state for his ward. Bowles v. Bowles, 249 Ky. 428, 60 S.W.2d 985, 1933 Ky. LEXIS 540 (Ky. 1933) (decided under prior law).

    In an action to sell land, the infant may be joined as a party plaintiff by his guardian and need not be made a defendant even though collateral and incidental relief is sought. Greenway's Guardian v. Greenway, 262 Ky. 818, 91 S.W.2d 553, 1936 Ky. LEXIS 110 (Ky. 1936) (decided under prior law).

    An action for the sale of indivisible property and distribution of the proceeds among the joint owners is one in which infants may be joined as plaintiffs by their guardians and in this character of action the infants need not be made defendants. Hume v. Chenault, 305 Ky. 68, 202 S.W.2d 1018, 1947 Ky. LEXIS 769 (Ky. 1947) (decided under prior law).

    In action where infant was a proper party plaintiff through his statutory guardian, the infant through the guardian had the right to allege such facts as entitled him to the relief sought, and when such facts were set out in the petition and were not controverted, they could be taken by the court as true just as if the pleader had been an adult and his allegations were undenied. Hume v. Chenault, 305 Ky. 68, 202 S.W.2d 1018, 1947 Ky. LEXIS 769 (Ky. 1947) (decided under prior law).

    33. — — Infants Not Parties.

    It is not indispensable that infant defendant be served with summons, but the appearance and answer of his guardian is all that is required or intended by the legislature. Shelby v. Harrison, 84 Ky. 144, 8 Ky. L. Rptr. 83, 1886 Ky. LEXIS 47 (Ky. Ct. App. 1886) (decided under prior law).

    In an action by a guardian for sale or division of property, it is not necessary that the ward should be a party; therefore, where he is made a defendant, it is not necessary that he should be served with process. Howard v. Singleton, 94 Ky. 336, 22 S.W. 337, 15 Ky. L. Rptr. 309, 1893 Ky. LEXIS 57 (Ky. 1893) (decided under prior law).

    A guardian may bring an action for his infant ward and obtain an order of court for a sale of joint property, without making the infant ward a plaintiff or defendant. Scott v. Graves, 153 Ky. 221, 154 S.W. 1084, 1913 Ky. LEXIS 803 (Ky. 1913) (decided under prior law).

    In a proceeding to sell land for the purpose of division among the joint owners, some of whom were infants and were made defendants, an appearance by the statutory guardian who filed an answer in their behalf was sufficient to bring the infants before the court. Pollard v. Hamilton, 179 Ky. 284, 200 S.W. 621, 1918 Ky. LEXIS 220 (Ky. 1918) (decided under prior law).

    In an action to sell a vested estate in real property jointly owned by two or more persons, if the estate in the possession or property cannot be divided without materially impairing its value, the guardian of an infant may join with the adult owners in his own name without making the infant either a party plaintiff or defendant. Smith v. Smith, 255 Ky. 191, 72 S.W.2d 425, 1934 Ky. LEXIS 168 (Ky. 1934) (decided under prior law).

    An infant’s guardian may bring a suit, or join in a suit, to sell lands without his ward being made either a party plaintiff or a defendant in the proceeding. Kidd v. Kidd, 276 Ky. 271, 124 S.W.2d 66, 1939 Ky. LEXIS 515 (Ky. 1939) (decided under prior law).

    Cited:

    Walton v. Lee, 634 S.W.2d 159, 1982 Ky. LEXIS 255 (Ky. 1982); Maynard v. Boggs, 735 S.W.2d 342, 1987 Ky. App. LEXIS 543 (Ky. Ct. App. 1987); Sterling Grace Mun. Secs. Corp. v. Central Bank & Trust Co., 926 S.W.2d 670, 1995 Ky. App. LEXIS 201 (Ky. Ct. App. 1995); Sterling Grace Mun. Secs. Corp. v. Central Bank & Trust Co., 926 S.W.2d 670, 1995 Ky. App. LEXIS 201 (Ky. Ct. App. 1995).

    389A.032. Private sale of property without prior judicial proceeding or judgment, but subject to court approval.

  • Without previous judicial proceeding or judgment, an interest in real property held by a fiduciary for the benefit of a ward, or by more than one (1) person or by an unknown heir may be sold by private sale subject to court approval. An action for approval of sale shall be brought in the manner provided for judicial approval prior to sale in KRS 389A.030 and 389A.035.
  • History.
    Enact. Acts 1984, ch. 9, § 1, effective February 6, 1984.

    • NOTES TO DECISIONS

    Cited:

    Thomas v. Turner, 736 S.W.2d 343, 1987 Ky. App. LEXIS 454 (Ky. Ct. App. 1987).

    Research References and Practice Aids

    Kentucky Bench & Bar.

    Collier, Property Sale in Estate Settlement, Volume 54, No. 1, Winter 1990 Ky. Bench & B. 31.

    Treatises

    Caldwell’s Kentucky Form Book, 5th Ed., Practice Context for Fiducial Sales, § 317.00.

    Caldwell’s Kentucky Form Book, 5th Ed., Practice Context for Partition and Judicial Sales, § 318.00.


    389A.035. Interests of persons unborn or not immediately ascertainable.

  • When two (2) or more persons share title to real estate but an interest therein may be possessed by persons unborn or not immediately ascertainable, an action for sale or division may be brought in the same manner as provided in KRS 389A.030 but the interest of the unborn or unascertainable persons, unless a living member of the class to which such persons belong who is sui juris is a party to the action, shall be represented by a guardian ad litem who is not acting in such capacity for any other party to the action. In the event of sale or division under this section, the court shall apply the provisions of subsection (6) of KRS 389A.030 to preserve the interest of the unborn or unascertainable persons until they are born, ascertained or the class to which they belong otherwise closes.
  • History.
    Enact. Acts 1980, ch. 87, § 7, effective July 15, 1980.

    • 1. Contingent Interest.

    Where a contingent interest in unborn children exists, real estate may not be conveyed by private sale. Blackaby v. Barnes, 587 S.W.2d 852, 1979 Ky. App. LEXIS 476 (Ky. Ct. App. 1979) (decided under prior law).

    389A.045. Short title.

  • This chapter shall be titled “Fiducial and Judicial Sales of Real Estate.”
  • History.
    Enact. Acts 1980, ch. 87, § 1, effective July 15, 1980.
